natural problem: What is the remainder of $8^6 + 7^7 + 6^8$ divided by 5?
natural solution: First of all, $6$ has a remainder of $1$ when divided by $5,$ thus any power of $6$ will have a remainder of $1$ when divided by $5.$ As for $7,$ it has a remainder of $2$ when divided by $5$, so let us look at the powers of $2$: \begin{align}

2^1 &\equiv 2 \pmod{5} \\ 2^2 &\equiv 4 \pmod{5} \\ 2^3 &\equiv 3 \pmod{5} \\ 2^4 &\equiv 1 \pmod{5}. \end{align}Since $2^4 \equiv 1 \pmod{5},$ we see that $2^{7} \equiv 2^3 \cdot 2^4 \equiv 3 \pmod{5},$ hence the remainder of $7^4$ when divided by $5$ is $3.$

Now, there is a bit of a shortcut we can use for $8.$ Since $8 \equiv -2 \pmod{5},$ we can see that $8^6 \equiv (-2)^6 \equiv 2^6 \equiv 2^2 \cdot 2^4 \equiv 4 \pmod {5},$ hence our desired remainder is $4.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y z :: real
assumes h0 : "x = 8 powr 6 + 7 powr 7 + 6 powr 8"
shows  "x mod 5 = 3"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the remainder of $8^6 + 7^7 + 6^8$ divided by 5? The final Answer is 3
 ### Proof
 First of all, $6$ has a remainder of $1$ when divided by $5,$ thus any power of $6$ will have a remainder of $1$ when divided by $5.$ As for $7,$ it has a remainder of $2$ when divided by $5$, so let us look at the powers of $2$: \begin{align}
 2^1 &\equiv 2 \pmod{5} \\ 2^2 &\equiv 4 \pmod{5} \\ 2^3 &\equiv 3 \pmod{5} \\ 2^4 &\equiv 1 \pmod{5}. \end{align}Since $2^4 \equiv 1 \pmod{5},$ we see that $2^{7} \equiv 2^3 \cdot 2^4 \equiv 3 \pmod{5},$ hence the remainder of $7^4$ when divided by $5$ is $3.$
 Now, there is a bit of a shortcut we can use for $8.$ Since $8 \equiv -2 \pmod{5},$ we can see that $8^6 \equiv (-2)^6 \equiv 2^6 \equiv 2^2 \cdot 2^4 \equiv 4 \pmod {5},$ hence our desired remainder is $4.$
 Adding them up, we have $4 + 3 + 1 \equiv \boxed{3} \pmod{5}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y z :: real
assumes h0 : "x = 8 powr 6 + 7 powr 7 + 6 powr 8"
shows  "x mod 5 = 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Calculate the remainder when the sum of 8 to the power of 6, 7 to the power of 7, and 6 to the power of 8 is divided by 5. The final answer is 3.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem 
fixes x y z :: nat
assumes h0 : "x = 8^6 + 7^7 + 6^8"
shows  "x mod 5 = 3"
a_1.formal solution:

 What is the remainder of $8^6 + 7^7 + 6^8$ divided by 5? The final Answer is 3
 ### Proof
 First of all, $6$ has a remainder of $1$ when divided by $5,$ thus any power of $6$ will have a remainder of $1$ when divided by $5.$ As for $7,$ it has a remainder of $2$ when divided by $5$, so let us look at the powers of $2$: \begin{align}

 Now, there is a bit of a shortcut we can use for $8.$ Since $8 \equiv -2 \pmod{5},$ we can see that $8^6 \equiv (-2)^6 \equiv 2^6 \equiv 2^2 \cdot 2^4 \equiv 4 \pmod {5},$ hence our desired remainder is $4.$
 Adding them up, we have $4 + 3 + 1 \equiv \boxed{3} \pmod{5}.$
 *)

theorem 
fixes x y z :: nat
assumes h0 : "x = 8^6 + 7^7 + 6^8"
shows  "x mod 5 = 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find the remainder when the sum of $8^6$, $7^7$, and $6^8$ is divided by 5. The final answer is 3.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y z :: real
assumes h0 : "x = 8 powr 6"
and h1 : "y = 7 powr 7"
and h2 : "z = 6 powr 8"
shows  "((x + y + z) mod 5) = 3"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the remainder of $8^6 + 7^7 + 6^8$ divided by 5? The final Answer is 3
 ### Proof
 First of all, $6$ has a remainder of $1$ when divided by $5,$ thus any power of $6$ will have a remainder of $1$ when divided by $5.$ As for $7,$ it has a remainder of $2$ when divided by $5$, so let us look at the powers of $2$: \begin{align}
 2^1 &\equiv 2 \pmod{5} \\ 2^2 &\equiv 4 \pmod{5} \\ 2^3 &\equiv 3 \pmod{5} \\ 2^4 &\equiv 1 \pmod{5}. \end{align}Since $2^4 \equiv 1 \pmod{5},$ we see that $2^{7} \equiv 2^3 \cdot 2^4 \equiv 3 \pmod{5},$ hence the remainder of $7^4$ when divided by $5$ is $3.$
 Now, there is a bit of a shortcut we can use for $8.$ Since $8 \equiv -2 \pmod{5},$ we can see that $8^6 \equiv (-2)^6 \equiv 2^6 \equiv 2^2 \cdot 2^4 \equiv 4 \pmod {5},$ hence our desired remainder is $4.$
 Adding them up, we have $4 + 3 + 1 \equiv \boxed{3} \pmod{5}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y z :: real
assumes h0 : "x = 8 powr 6"
and h1 : "y = 7 powr 7"
and h2 : "z = 6 powr 8"
shows  "((x + y + z) mod 5) = 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

fixes a b c :: real
assumes h0 : "a = 8 powr 6"
and h1 : "b = 7 powr 7"
and h2 : "c = 6 powr 8"
shows  "(a + b + c) mod 5 = 3"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the remainder of $8^6 + 7^7 + 6^8$ divided by 5? The final Answer is 3
 ### Proof
 First of all, $6$ has a remainder of $1$ when divided by $5,$ thus any power of $6$ will have a remainder of $1$ when divided by $5.$ As for $7,$ it has a remainder of $2$ when divided by $5$, so let us look at the powers of $2$: \begin{align}

 Adding them up, we have $4 + 3 + 1 \equiv \boxed{3} \pmod{5}.$
 *)

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes remainder :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. remainder n = n mod 5"
shows  "remainder (8^6 + 7^7 + 6^8) = 3"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the remainder of $8^6 + 7^7 + 6^8$ divided by 5? The final Answer is 3
 ### Proof
 First of all, $6$ has a remainder of $1$ when divided by $5,$ thus any power of $6$ will have a remainder of $1$ when divided by $5.$ As for $7,$ it has a remainder of $2$ when divided by $5$, so let us look at the powers of $2$: \begin{align}
 2^1 &\equiv 2 \pmod{5} \\ 2^2 &\equiv 4 \pmod{5} \\ 2^3 &\equiv 3 \pmod{5} \\ 2^4 &\equiv 1 \pmod{5}. \end{align}Since $2^4 \equiv 1 \pmod{5},$ we see that $2^{7} \equiv 2^3 \cdot 2^4 \equiv 3 \pmod{5},$ hence the remainder of $7^4$ when divided by $5$ is $3.$
 Now, there is a bit of a shortcut we can use for $8.$ Since $8 \equiv -2 \pmod{5},$ we can see that $8^6 \equiv (-2)^6 \equiv 2^6 \equiv 2^2 \cdot 2^4 \equiv 4 \pmod {5},$ hence our desired remainder is $4.$
 Adding them up, we have $4 + 3 + 1 \equiv \boxed{3} \pmod{5}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes remainder :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. remainder n = n mod 5"
shows  "remainder (8^6 + 7^7 + 6^8) = 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
